sections.heading: Brightness and Photostability of Emerging Red and Near-IR
Philipp Reineck,* Adam Francis, Antony Orth, Desmond Wai Mo Lau,
Reece David Valmont Nixon-Luke, Ishan Das Rastogi, Wan Aizuddin Wan Razali,
Nicole Maree Cordina, Lindsay Marie Parker, Varun Kumaraswamy Annayya Sreenivasan,
Louise Jennifer Brown, and Brant Cameron Gibson*
sections.text:
DOI: 10.1002/adom.201600212
to investigate structures and dynamics in biological systems, which are often not accessible by other imaging techniques. By far the most commonly used class of materials in fluorescence based bio imaging is organic fluorophores (OFs).[1] They combine small size (≤1 nm) with high extinction crosssection and fluo rescence quantum yield and are avail able throughout the visible spectrum to the near infrared (NIR). However, a major drawback is their propensity to photobleach as a result of the imaging process; often within a few seconds. The synthesis of efficient, watersoluble, and photostable fluorophores in the near IR (>700 nm) remains challenging despite decades of molecular engineering.[2] The NIR spectral region is particularly important in biological systems due to the relatively weak light absorption and autofluorescence of biological matter com pared to the green and blue parts of the spectrum.[3]
Today, other fluorescent materials outperform OFs in some applications, but this usually comes at a cost. For example, semiconductor nanoparticles commonly referred to as quantum dots (QDs) exhibit higher brightness (in a one molecule–one particle comparison) and higher photo stability than OFs,[4] but are also larger (usually 3–10 nm).
Many novel fluorescent nanomaterials exhibit radically different optical properties compared to organic fluorophores that are still the most extensively used class of fluorophores in biology today. Assessing the practical impact of these optical differences for bioimaging experiments is challenging due to a lack of published quantitative benchmarking data. This study therefore directly and quantitatively compares the brightness and photostability of representatives from seven classes of fluorescent materials in spectroscopy and fluorescence microscopy experiments for the first time. These material classes are: organic dyes, semiconductor quantum dots, fluorescent beads, carbon dots, gold nanoclusters, nanodiamonds, and nanorubies. The relative brightness of each material is determined and the minimum material concentrations required to generate sufficient contrast in a fluorescence microscopy image are assessed. The influence of optical filters used for imaging is also discussed and suitable filter combinations are identified. The photostability of all materials is determined under typical imaging conditions and the number of images that can be acquired is inferred. The results are expected to facilitate the transition of novel fluorescent materials from physics and chemistry into biology laboratories.

1. Introduction
Nanometer sized fluorescent probes create high optical con trast in biological samples where other techniques such as brightfield or phase contrast microscopy fail. Through the labeling of specific sites of interest they also provide a means

Quantum dots are usually composed of toxic elements (e.g., Cd, Se, Te), which has so far prevented their use for in vivo diagnostic applications, even though the toxicity of QD particles is still under debate.[5,6] Similarly, fluorescent nanodiamonds exhibit extremely high photostability and are considered to be nontoxic,[7,8] but are not as bright as OFs or QDs.[9] Because of these tradeoffs, it is imperative to have a good understanding of the optical properties of emerging fluorescent materials relative to established ones to enable users of these materials to make an informed decision on which material is best suited for their respective imaging application.
Despite a large number of review articles in the field, up until now, a thorough and direct experimental comparison of emerging and established fluorescent nanomaterials has not been performed. In this study, we experimentally com pare the optical properties of selected established as well as emerging materials fluorescing between 600 and 800 nm, with a focus on brightness and photostability as two major properties of interest in most fluorescence imaging experi ments. Commercially available materials are used wherever possible to enable users to access the materials investigated here. However, this also means that the materials may not be as bright or photostable as stateoftheart materials synthe sized in research laboratories today. The selection of mate rials in the current study is by no means comprehensive. Only one representative of each material type is reported and the properties between different types of QDs, for example, vary greatly. Nonetheless, due to the enormous differences in brightness, photostability, and size of the investigated mate rials, the results presented here will assist users who are interested in employing new materials in their experiments in answering important practical questions such as: can this material be imaged on a commercial fluorescence micro scope?; what concentration is needed?; how bright will it be relative to a common fluorophore?; and what length of time can imaging be performed for?
Throughout this manuscript we refer to the light emitted by the nanomaterials as “fluorescence” for simplicity. However, please note that the emission of light by one of the materials – nanoruby – is via phosphorescence and not fluorescence. This distinction is not relevant to any of the properties discussed here.

sections.heading: 2.1. Material Properties
sections.text:
Extinction and fluorescence spectra of the materials investigated in this study are shown in Figure 1A,B, respectively; and some of their most important physical and chemical properties are summarized in Table 1. All materials except Au nano clusters and nanorubies are commercially available. Gold nanoclusters were synthesized following a reported protocol[10] and nano rubies were fabricated via ball milling of bulk ruby samples (see the Experimental Section). Alexa 647 is a commonly used OF from the cyanine dye family (see Figure S1 in the Supporting Information for chemical structure). Dyes with very similar optical properties are Cy5 or Atto 647. Other widely employed materials are core–shell semiconductor QDs and socalled “fluorescent beads,” which are fluorescent dyes embedded in a polymer or silica matrix. Here we have chosen a QD with a CdS/ CdSe core and a ZnS shell. The fluorescent beads are composed of Chromeon 642 embedded in a polyacrylonitrile particle. Carbon dots (cdots) consist mostly of graphite, but also contain significant amounts of oxygen and nitrogen.[11] The nanodia monds employed here are fabricated from bulk highpressure hightemperature (HPHT) diamonds through a milling process (this is in contrast to detonation diamond, which is recovered from a detonation soot). Through high energy irradiation and annealing, the socalled nitrogenvacancy (NV) center is created in the diamond, rendering the material fluorescent.[12] Nanoru bies are chromium doped aluminum oxide particles fabricated through milling of bulk ruby samples. Cr gives rise to phospho rescence analogous to the bulk material and the particles also show the typical narrow emission of ruby at 694 nm.[13] Gold nanoclusters (Au NCs) consist of few tens of Au atoms and are fluorescent – unlike larger (>2 nm) gold particles, which do not fluoresce significantly. Ligands are an important part of Au NCs and together with the number of atoms in the cluster deter mine their optical properties.[10,14]
Both the extinction spectra of Alexa 647 and beads (Figure 1A) show the characteristic absorption peaks of poly aromatic molecules, while the spectrum of the beads has the scattering signal from the polymer matrix superimposed. Nano diamonds and nanorubies with diameters larger than 100 nm also strongly scatter light, with these broad features dominating

The extinction spectra of Au NCs, cdots, and QDs, which are too small to significantly scatter light, are dominated by optical absorption of the mate rials and ligands they consist of as well as smaller excitonic features.[14,15] (In cdots the absorption is most likely caused by a high density of πelectrons in the particles.[16]) Only the fluo rescence spectrum of cdots was found to significantly depend on the excitation wavelength, in agreement with literature reports.[17] To obtain the emission spectrum shown in Figure 1B with the emission maximum close to 650 nm, the cdots were excited in the green (around 530 nm) even though they are more efficiently excited in the ultraviolet (UV). Quantum dots, Alexa 647, and fluorescent beads all exhibited a narrow fluorescence spectrum (35–45 nm, fullwidthathalfmaximum (FWHM)) compared to cdots (190 nm FWHM), nanodiamonds (120 nm FWHM), and Au NCs (130 nm FWHM). Nanorubies show the narrowest emission with a spectral width of only a few nanometers.

sections.heading: 2.2. Brightness
sections.text:
The fluorescence brightness (B) of a material is a fundamental parameter in every fluorescence spectroscopy or microscopy experiment. It is generally defined as
B ε= Γ (1) where ε is the absorption crosssection of one molecule or particle and Γ is the fluorescence quantum yield of the mate rial. This implicitly means that, for example, one fluorophore is directly compared to one nanodiamond, even though their diameters are two orders of magnitude apart. (Also commonly used is the molar absorption coefficient εm, which is a mol ecule/particle number based quantity as well.) In cases where only a few labels are required and individual sites in a biolog ical sample are to be identified or tracked over time, a particle number based comparison, e.g., of a material’s brightness, is justified. However, if the goal is to minimize the total amount (e.g., mass) of material used to label a biological sample, one should compare the brightness of equal mass or volume of material per volume of solvent.
Furthermore, Equation (1) does not take into account the spectral shape of the fluorescence of the material or consider the wavelengths at which the material can be excited. Both are very important for practical purposes since they each strongly affect the background fluorescence signal and the choice of excitation source and filter set to be employed.
We have used fluorescence spectroscopy to determine the brightness of each nanomaterial relative to Alexa 647 (and thereby relative to one another). All materials were dispersed in deionized (DI) water at a concentration yielding an optical den sity (OD) ≤0.1 at the excitation wavelength to avoid reabsorption effects. Excitation was carried out as close to the excitation max imum of the respective material as practically feasible using a tunable white light laser source (see the Experimental Section and Table S2 (Supporting Information)). A linear relationship between the fluorescence intensity and the following para meters was verified: excitation intensity, material concentra tion, and integration time (data not shown). Different material concentrations were necessary to satisfy the ≤0.1 OD criterion and different integration times were needed to collect sufficient fluorescence and to prevent detector saturation for the dimmer and brighter materials, respectively (see the Supporting Infor mation for details).
Relative brightness values were determined by rescaling the emission spectrum of each sample to account for dif ferences in material concentrations, integration times, and excitation intensities, followed by integration over the entire emission spectrum. Figure 2A (blue bars) shows the meas ured relative brightness of all materials based on equal mass concentrations (mg mL−1) in DI water. Here, Alexa 647 is two orders of magnitude brighter than quantum dots and at least three orders of magnitude brighter than Au NCs, cdots, nan odiamonds, and nanorubies. It is also more than two orders of magnitude brighter than beads mainly because a signifi cant fraction of the mass of beads is nonfluorescent polymer. It is important to note that the comparison is based on equal mass concentrations: even though an individual quantum dot is significantly brighter than a single Alexa dye, since the weight of a single QD is more than two orders of magnitude larger than that of a dye, the equivalent molar concentration of Alexa is about two orders of magnitude higher than that of the QDs.

Experimental brightness values are also compared to the relative brightness calculated from literature values of extinc tion crosssection and fluorescence quantum yield (Figure 2, grey bars). In most cases, experimental and calculated results are generally in good agreement (within error). For beads and Au NCs, the experimental value is significantly larger than the calculated one. The quantum yield of the OFs inside the beads is only reported in water (not in the polymer matrix) and also the number of dyes per particle could only be estimated based on polymer particle size and density and an extinction spectrum of the beads in solution. Furthermore, scattering of light by the polymer matrix artificially elongates the optical path, leading to an increase in observed fluorescence (but not the calculated fluorescence brightness). The latter is also true for nanodiamonds and nanorubies, whose sizes are also large enough to significantly scatter visible light. In the case of Au NCs, the mass concentration of material in solution refers to the amount of gold used for the synthesis only and does not take into account the ligands. However, the ratio of gold atoms to ligands for Au NCs is estimated to be 21:8 for one particle.[9] If ligands were included, the mass concentration of Au NCs used in experiments would increase and could explain the observed discrepancy.
It is instructive to renormalize brightness values to equal molar concentrations, i.e., to compare the brightness of one molecule or particle with one another (Figure 2B). These values were inferred from the data in Figure 2A based on the sizes and densities (or molecular weight in case of Alexa 647) of the mate rials (see Table S5, Supporting Information). Here, the result is dominated by the size of the materials: despite the fact that on a mass basis nanodiamonds and nanorubies are the least bright materials, they become the second brightest particles after beads. Similar to beads, nanodiamonds and nanorubies contain hundreds of emitters in each particle, making them sig nificantly brighter than Alexa 647 and quantum dots.
The data shown in Figure 2 is obtained from analysis of the entire emission spectrum of each material using a tun able laser as an excitation source and a spectrometer to collect the emission. However, most commercial fluorescence micro scopes only have a limited number of excitation sources (EX)
and emission filters (EM) available. We therefore explored how the materials can be imaged using a commercial widefield fluorescence microscope. Commercial fluorescence micro scopes, like the Olympus IX83 used in this study, are fitted with four matching excitation sources and emission filters in the blue, green, yellow, and red part of the visible spectrum (see Figure S4, Supporting Information). We used a standard filter set, but allowed “nonstandard combinations” of EX and EM, e.g., EX at 560 nm and EM at 692 nm to better image each material. We found that all materials except Alexa 647, QDs, and beads require nonstandard combinations of filters to enable good imaging; mainly due to their larger Stokes shift. (For QDs it is also advantageous to use a nonstandard combination, but not necessary). Generally, the excitation sources and emission filters of the microscope should be chosen to be as close to the absorption and emission maxima of each material, respectively. However, in practice, other considerations such as the excita tion of background fluorescence and the quality of the optical filters in the microscope will strongly influence this choice.

Using the imaging conditions summarized in Table 2, and based on the SBR values reported in Figure 3B, the amount of fluorescent material needed in a sample of 50 μm thickness to obtain an average SBR of 1 or higher was calculated. This calculation is based on the assumption that the fluorescence intensity is proportional to the concentration of the material. The results are included in Table 2. Although these values are approximations only, they do give the user a starting point to design their bioimaging assay. Relative to Alexa 647, signifi cantly higher concentrations (mg mL−1) must be used for all other materials in order to obtain a SBR comparable to that of OFs. However, the relatively fast bleaching of OFs also means
that the SBR value will decrease very rapidly, while other mate rials can be imaged for longer time periods without a signifi cant change in the observed contrast. We also assume that the fluorescent material is evenly distributed within the sample. In cases where only a few sites of interest are labeled, then this assumption is not correct and far more material may be con centrated in a small region of interest, yielding much higher SBR values and local image contrast. The labeling process itself is of course of critical importance and can be extremely com plex depending on the biological sample, but is beyond the scope of this present study.
Based on the optical properties of the materials we have also identified combinations of dichroic mirrors and emission fil ters, which are better suited than the standard filters available in most commercial fluorescence microscopes for imaging these novel materials. All of these filters are commercially available and are listed in Table 2. They are chosen to maxi mize the collection of fluorescence and minimize the impact of autofluorescence.

sections.heading: 2.3. Photostability
sections.text:
The photostability of a fluorescent label determines how many images of a sample can be obtained during the course of an experiment. Before an image can even be acquired, the region of interest must be found and the ideal focal plane needs to be identified. Depending on the experimental conditions, sig nificant photobleaching can occur before the first image is recorded. Furthermore, photobleaching significantly compli cates any quantification of fluorescence signals. Therefore, high photostability is of critical importance to virtually all samples, not only those that are to be imaged over longer periods of time.
We have determined the photostability of the discussed materials under typical widefield fluorescence imaging con ditions. Figure 4 shows the normalized fluorescence inten sity as a function of time under continuous illumination at 10.6 mW (≈10.7 W cm−2) using a 40× objective and the EX and
EM conditions as listed in Table 2. Only Alexa 647 and beads show a single exponential decrease over time. Carbon dots and Au NCs can be well approximated with two exponentials, while nanodiamonds and nanorubies show perfect photosta bility (over hours and days, data not shown). The QD fluores cence increases over time for several minutes before starting to bleach, which is a known phenomenon and briefly discussed in the next paragraph. Since most photobleaching traces do not show a simple exponential decrease over time, we use the time τ at which the fluorescence intensity decreases to 50% of its initial value as a photostability metric. While the emission of Alexa 647 decreases by 50% within about 8 s, Au NCs need 27 s, beads 85 s, cdots 2.5 min, and QDs 25 min (see Figure S3, Supporting Information) to reach this point (see Table 2).
A major cause for bleaching in OFs is oxidation.[18] The fact that the OFs in beads are embedded in a polymer matrix most likely shields them from oxygen and thereby makes them more photostable. Gold NCs and cdots have been reported to be more photostable than dyes,[14,17] while the photophysics of the bleaching process in these materials is not yet well understood. The increase in fluorescence intensity of the QDs observed here has also been reported in literature for CdSe QDs dispersed in water and has been attributed to the passi vation of the QD surface by water molecules during the initial photoexcitation.[19] Upon continued illumination, QDs bleach as well (and eventually aggregate), but at a slower rate than the OFs, Au NCs, and cdots (see Figure S3, Supporting Informa tion). Only nanodiamonds and nanorubies show ideal photosta bility over time. Both NV centers in diamond and Cr dopants in alumina are firmly embedded in the crystal lattice of their host materials, both of which are extremely hard and chemically inert. We have also calculated the number of images that can be recorded before the fluorescence intensity drops to 50% relative to Alexa 647 to relate the bleaching traces to a more practical quantity (Table 2, second last column).

Briefly, human U87 MG astrocyte cells were cultured onto sterile, RNAsefree coverslips for 24 h prior to fixation in 4% formaldehyde for 10 min. Cells were permea bilized with 70% ethanol for 30 min at 4 °C and then stained in phosphate buffered saline solution with 0.01% Tween20 for 48 h at 4 °C with 5 μg mL−1 streptavidin conjugated Alexa 647, streptavidin conjugated nanodiamonds (see the Sup porting Information for nanodiamond bioconjugation pro tocol), and unconjugated nanorubies. Solutions were removed and coverslips were washed before being mounted onto slides with antifade mounting media containing DAPI (4′,6diami dino2phenylindole, see the Experimental Section for details). The samples were imaged using the setup described in Table 2, but with a 100× oil immersion objective with a numerical aper ture (NA) of 1.4. In Figure 5, Alexa 647, nanodiamonds and nanorubies are shown in red and DAPI in blue. The same mass concentration was used for all materials for staining. Nanodiamonds and nanorubies, and small aggregates of those particles can clearly be identified inside and also to a lesser degree around the astrocytes. The cells show autofluorescence in the fluorescence emission window centered around 692 nm used for imaging here. This is seen in the nanodiamond and nanoruby images as a homogenous red coloration in the vicinity of the cell nuclei. Due to the weak aggregation of the nanodia mond and nanoruby particles, their fluorescence appears to be more local (as opposed to evenly distributed within the cell in the case of Alexa 647), which increases their contrast locally and makes them extremely well suited for the identification of individual sites of interest, if specific targeting can be achieved. Far fewer nanorubies are present in the images shown here, presumably due to the fact that these were not bioconjugated. Nonetheless, individual particles and small aggregates (as well as one large aggregate) can be clearly identified throughout the image (also see higher magnification inset in Figure 5). Due to the long emission lifetime of ruby on the millisecond time scale, timegating can be used to remove autofluorescence sig nals to obtain a backgroundfree image.[13] Figure 5 illustrates the extreme photostability of nanodiamond and nanoruby par ticles compared to Alexa 647 even at very moderate widefield illumination intensities of 1.5 mW (≈8.8 W cm−2). While Alexa 647 has almost completely bleached after 40 s of continuous illumination, the nanodiamonds and nanorubies show no change at all.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusion
sections.text:
We have determined the relative brightness of seven emerging and established nanomaterials using fluorescence spectroscopy and microscopy. Our results highlight the importance of distin guishing between molar and massbased concentrations when comparing optical properties such as absorption coefficient and brightness. On the basis of equal mass concentrations, the organic fluorophore Alexa 647 is two orders of magnitude brighter than the CdSe/CdSZns quantum dots and —three to four orders of magnitude brighter than the carbondots, Au NCs, nanodiamonds, and nanorubies investigated here. These results are in agreement with brightness values calcu lated from absorption coefficients and fluorescent quantum yields. Yet, on the basis of equal molar concentrations (using particle molarity), fluorescent beads, nanodiamonds, and nano rubies become the brightest emitters by almost two orders of magnitude.
We have investigated the signaltobackground ratio (or con trast) obtained when imaging the materials with a fluorescence microscope. We demonstrate that all materials create sufficient contrast when imaged using a commercial fluorescence micro scope, while the brightness differences established in spectros copy experiments are reflected by the obtained SBR values. Our results emphasize that in order to use new materials to their full potential, the filter sets of fluorescence microscopes must be tailored to the properties of each material. Carbon dots, Au NCs, nanodiamonds, and nanorubies all have a significantly larger Stokesshift than standard EX and EM combinations and the first three also have a much broader emission spectrum than the 30–40 nm wide bandpass often used as an emission filter.
Only nanodiamonds and nanorubies showed no change in emission intensity over time. Even under the relatively low excitation intensity of a widefield microscope (as com pared to a confocal microscope) Alexa 647 almost completely bleached within the first 30 s of illumination, while Au NCs, beads, and cdots exhibited intermediate levels of photosta bility. The QDs’ fluorescence was found to first increase and then photobleach upon further excitation, but display a very high level of stability. In particular in the context of abso lute quantification of fluorescence signal, and the long term imaging of samples, nanodiamonds and nanorubies hold the greatest potential.
In general, the trade off is clear; for ideal photostability one has to sacrifice brightness and vice versa. The semiconductor quantum dots investigated here are probably the best compro mise between the two, but toxicity remains a concern. For the brightest fluorescence per material mass, organic dyes are the material of choice. For quantitative long term imaging, nano diamonds and nanorubies are excellent materials. The prac tical quantification of brightness and photostability carried out in this study will help researchers in this area to consider this tradeoff more clearly. However, the progress in the area of new and novel fluorescent nanomaterials is extremely rapid and that the properties of other materials of the same materials type, say carbon dots, may already have significantly improved in labora toryscale production and may become commercially available soon.

sections.heading: 4. Experimental Section
sections.text:
Materials: Gold nanoclusters and nanorubies were synthesized and fabricated inhouse as described below. All other materials were purchased from the following suppliers: Alexa Fluor 647, carboxylic acid: ThermoFisher Scientific, USA; CdSeS/ZnS alloyed quantum dots, carboxylic acid, and nano beads based on polyacrylonitrile (beads), Chromeon 642marked, carboxylated: SigmaAldrich, USA; 120 nm fluorescent nanodiamond: Adamas Nano, USA; Carbon dots, red: Nanopartz, USA. All materials were used as received and as synthesized, diluted in DI water as required, and stored in the dark at 4 °C. Gold nanoclusters were synthesized following a reported protocol.[9] Briefly: 5 mg of reduced glutathione (SigmaAlrich, USA) was dissolved in 1.8 mL of 50 × 10−3 m sodium acetate buffer of pH 7.46. This solution was cooled in an ice bath and 1 mg of HAuCl4 (SigmaAlrich, USA) was added under mild stirring and stirred for at least 3 min. 200 μL of an icecold, freshly prepared 2 mg mL−1 aqueous solution of NaBH4 (SigmaAlrich, USA) was slowly added to the mixture and allowed to react for 1 h. Nanoruby particles were produced from synthetic ruby crystals procured from Henan Union Abrasive Corp., China using highenergy ball milling, following an established protocol for producing nanoalumina.[20]
Spectroscopy and Brightness Measurements: Extinction spectra were obtained using an Agilent 8453 UV–visible spectrometer. Fluorescence spectra were recorded by using a Fianium WhiteLase SC400 (Fianium Ltd, Great Britain) pulsed laser as an excitation source and collection of the emitted light by a Princeton Instruments Acton SpectraPro SP2500 spectrometer fitted with a PIXIS chargecoupled device (CCD) camera (Princeton Instruments, USA). Excitation intensities were determined using a PM100D power meter (Thorlabs Inc., USA). Emission spectra were collected between 574 and 925 nm, background corrected and corrected for differences in material concentration, excitation intensity, and integration time. In the case of the beads sample, the scattering signal at the excitation wavelength of 600 nm was removed from the spectrum. Figure 2A “Experiment” shows the integrated counts for each spectrum.
The mass based theoretical brightness values Bw were calculated using a modified Equation (1) Bw = εwΓ, with the mass based extinction coefficient εw. The particle/molecule number based theoretical values Bm were calculated using Bm = εmΓ, where εm was calculated from εw by εm = εwmNPNA, where mNP and NA are the mass of one particle or molecule and Avogadro constant, respectively (see Table S5 in the Supporting Information for details).
Wide-Field Fluorescence Imaging: Fluorescence images were obtained using a Olympus IX83 frame, 40× (NA 0.95) or 100× (NA 1.4) objectives (SP40X/UPLSAPO100XO, Olympus, Japan), fitted with a Hamamatsu ORCAFlash4.0 digital CMOS camera (Hamamatsu Photonics, Japan). A SPECTRA X light engine (Lumencor Inc, USA) was used for excitation and the power calibrated with a PM100D power meter. See the Supporting Information for all specifications, including dichroics and emission filters. Glass capillaries (No 5001050, VitroCom, USA) were used as received, brought into contact with the nanomaterial solution, and the solution was allowed to fill the capillary via capillary forces. Average fluorescence intensities IS and IB inside the capillaries were determined using ImageJ.[21] For bleaching experiments, in an area of ca. 35 μm2 in the center of the capillary, the fluorescence intensity was averaged and it was ensured that diffusion from unilluminated areas of the capillary into the field of view did not affect the measurement by calculating the mean square displacement due to Brownian motion based on particle size given in Table 1. The cell imaging was performed with a 100× oil objective (NA 1.4).
Cell Culturing and Staining: Human U87 MG human astrocyte cells were grown in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium with high glucose that was supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (12003C, SigmaAldrich, Australian origin), and 1% antibioticantimycotic (10 000 IU mL−1 penicillin, 10 000 μg mL−1 streptomycin) and 25 μg mL−1 of Fungizone antimycotic (15240062, ThermoFisher, USA). U87 MG astrocyte cells were a generous gift from Prof. Gilles Guillemin (Macquarie University, Sydney, Australia). Cells were maintained in a humidified incubator with 95% air and a 5% CO2 atmosphere at 37 °C. All cells were subcultured onto sterile, RNAsefree

Cells were permeabilized with 70% EtOH for 30 min at 4 °C and then stained in phosphate buffered saline solution with 0.01% tween20 (PBT) for 48 h at 4 °C with 5 μg mL−1 streptavidin conjugated Alexa 647 (ThermoFisher, USA), 5 μg mL−1 streptavidin conjugated 100 nm nanodiamonds (Academia Sinica, Taiwan), and 5 μg mL−1 of unconjugated ca. 100 nm sized nanorubies (produced inhouse). The particle material, size, and surface groups were provided by the sup­ plier except for nanorubies and Au nanoclusters, where the size was determined by dynamic light scattering and material and surface groups were obtained from literature reports.[10,20] Excitation and emission maxima were determined experimentally, except for Alexa 647 and beads, where sup­ plier values are given.

metadata.abstractText: DOI: 10.1002/adom.201600212 to investigate structures and dynamics in biological systems, which are often not accessible by other imaging techniques. By far the most commonly used class of materials in fluorescence based bio­ imaging is organic fluorophores (OFs).[1] They combine small size (≤1 nm) with high extinction cross­section and fluo­ rescence quantum yield and are avail­ able throughout the visible spectrum to the near infrared (NIR). However, a major drawback is their propensity to photobleach as a result of the imaging process; often within a few seconds. The synthesis of efficient, water­soluble, and photostable fluorophores in the near IR (>700 nm) remains challenging despite decades of molecular engineering.[2] The NIR spectral region is particularly important in biological systems due to the relatively weak light absorption and autofluorescence of biological matter com­ pared to the green and blue parts of the spectrum.[3] Today, other fluorescent materials outperform OFs in some applications, but this usually comes at a cost. For example, semiconductor nanoparticles commonly referred to as quantum dots (QDs) exhibit higher brightness (in a one molecule–one particle comparison) and higher photo­ stability than OFs,[4] but are also larger (usually 3–10 nm). Many novel fluorescent nanomaterials exhibit radically different optical properties compared to organic fluorophores that are still the most extensively used class of fluorophores in biology today. Assessing the practical impact of these optical differences for bioimaging experiments is challenging due to a lack of published quantitative benchmarking data. This study therefore directly and quantitatively compares the brightness and photostability of representatives from seven classes of fluorescent materials in spectroscopy and fluorescence microscopy experiments for the first time. These material classes are: organic dyes, semiconductor quantum dots, fluorescent beads, carbon dots, gold nanoclusters, nanodiamonds, and nanorubies. The relative brightness of each material is determined and the minimum material concentrations required to generate sufficient contrast in a fluorescence microscopy image are assessed. The influence of optical filters used for imaging is also discussed and suitable filter combinations are identified. The photostability of all materials is determined under typical imaging conditions and the number of images that can be acquired is inferred. The results are expected to facilitate the transition of novel fluorescent materials from physics and chemistry into biology laboratories.
